sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight. Here are your headlines.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Fresh efforts to rescue civilians trapped in Mariupol remain on a knife edge.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The Red Cross says it hopes to get more people out today, but Ukraine says Russia has blocked some buses from leaving and seized humanitarian aid.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Russia accuses Ukrainian helicopters of attacking a fuel depot.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: If confirmed, it would be the first time Russia has reported a Ukrainian airstrike on its territory since the war began.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: China says it will push for peace its own way in Ukraine at its first summit with the EU in two years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: EU chief von der Leyen warns China of the consequences if it helps Russia's war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey. Good to have you with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Up to 2,000 people have been evacuated from the city of Mariupol through the latest openings of humanitarian corridors, making their escape on buses supplied by Kyiv. The International Committee of the Red Cross is still hoping to carry out evacuations after receiving assurances from Russian and Ukrainian officials to allow safe passage. The aid organization says around 150,000 people remain trapped there. Ukraine's government welcomed the evacuation efforts, but has accused Russia of stealing much-needed humanitarian supplies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04

We're negotiating the return of buses so that the residents of Melitopol can leave for Saporizhia tomorrow.

sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, Russia says an oil depot near the border with Ukraine was attacked by helicopter gunships. Officials from the Belgorod region say that two Ukrainian helicopters crossed the border and struck the facility with missiles. Now, if confirmed, it would be the first engagement by Ukraine against Russia on Russian soil. However, Ukraine's foreign minister says he can neither confirm nor deny that Kyiv was behind the operation. Well, tracking the latest developments across Ukraine is our correspondent Sasha Vakulina, who joins me in the studio.

Now, all the corridors in that area, this is the Melitopol to Zaporizhia. Now all the corridors in that area, this is the southeastern area, the Azov Sea, they're all going to Zaporizhia. This is the big city that is in the region. Now the one from Melitopol worked but the one from Mariupol, this is where it gets really unclear because from what we know the buses were supposed to deliver first humanitarian aid also to Mariupol and then to take people from there and to take them to Zaporizhia.

But right now the Russian soldiers stopped them and they just wait something.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The EU and China have held their first high-level summit since 2020, with the bloc's leaders speaking virtually to President Xi Jinping.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The two discussed the war in Ukraine with Brussels seeking Beijing's help to end the conflict. But China says it disapproves of solving problems through sanctions and partly blamed the war on NATO's expansion. Commission President Ursula von der Leyen has warned China that it will suffer what she called reputational damage in Europe if it aids Moscow's war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: China should, if not support, at least not interfere with our sanctions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: We discussed that and also the fact that no European citizen would understand any support to Russia's ability to wage war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Moreover, it would lead to a major reputation or reputational damage for China here in Europe. Well, let's get the latest on those talks with our correspondent Shona Murray, who is in Brussels for us. Shona, the EU is making its view clear, I suppose, that China shouldn't block sanctions and it shouldn't also help Russia's war efforts. So how did that go down with the Chinese delegation?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, there's fairly low expectations for this summit anyway, and so that wasn't proved wrong.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: We heard from a Chinese statement subsequent to the meetings that China is saying that it always pursues a foreign policy of peace, that always pursues a foreign policy of peace, one that protects the UN Charter, that protects the sovereign right of each member state, including the territorial integrity of each member state, which is obviously questionable because the situation in Ukraine is one of invasion by one country against an independent other country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: We don't think it went down too well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Xi Jinping then said to Ursula von der Leyen that the EU and China should continue talks on this matter. But as you said there at the start, Helena, the Chinese position tends to be similar to the line that comes from the Kremlin, which is that the invasion was the responsibility of NATO.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Now, EU chief von der Leyen spoke of consequences of helping Russia. The EU and China have trade worth around two billion dollars a day. Will this likely weigh on the minds of Chinese leaders? Well that was the point of today's summit from an EU perspective. Really that was the highlight. That was what the EU wanted to deliver to the Chinese government was the repercussions, potential repercussions, if China were to support Russia in any way, economic, military, or to circumvent the sanctions which would impede how effective they are, that there would be repercussions. They didn't get into the details of that because the feeling was in Brussels that they didn't want to seem to be threatening, but they point out to China that the EU and China are each other's largest trading partners. About 14 percent of China's trade is with the EU. Two percent is with Russia and China. And so that is something that the EU very much wants to sort of hammer home insofar as is possible. But I think the position is still open. The EU and in particular the US, we're very much watching what china does and the us in particular joe biden we heard him last week saying that there would be strong repercussions for china's sanctions if it were to appear to support russia so it's it's an ongoing discussion helena all right shona murray in brussels thanks a lot shona well russia's war in ukraine has pulled millions of people's lives apart but in the face of death and destruction, it's also brought people in Ukraine together, igniting the spirits of resilience and charity across the nation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Tom Hill reports now.

Two weeks ago, Kathy Wheatley met Ivana Holub and her three children on the Ukrainian border with Romania and brought them back to her home in Ireland. Tom Hill, Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: An accident at a mine in central Serbia has left at least eight people dead and another 18 wounded.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Part of the Soko mine pit partially collapsed shortly after 5am local time, releasing methane gas and trapping miners.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Around 49 people were on shift at the time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: There have been several serious accidents there since it began operating in the early 1990s.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: 20 people in the UK government have been sent fines of Â£50, around 60 euros each, by email from the Metropolitan Police it follows the investigation to the so-called partygate scandal after claims of breaking covert measures during lockdowns it's unknown who the individuals are who've received the penalties inflation in the eurozone has hit its highest level in 25 years piling pressure on the European Central Bank to raise interest rates consumers across the 19 countries using the euro have seen energy costs skyrocket, something that doesn't look like it'll be changing anytime soon, particularly as the war in Ukraine continues. David Bellamy reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Inflation in the eurozone climbed to 7.5% in March, its highest level since the Euro began in 1997.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The European Union statistics agency Eurostat measured consumer prices in all of the 19 countries that use the currency.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: February's rate was 5.9%, which was also a record, as were the four months before that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Eurostat said energy costs rose nearly 45% last month in the EU.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: March's rate was the first time that the figure takes into account the war in Ukraine, and it's the clearest sign yet that rising energy prices are squeezing consumers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And prices are rising not only in Europe but across the world, which has the potential to cause social and political unrest. The European Central Bank is now under pressure to raise interest rates but historically speaking they're still very low at just 0.5 of a percent. Across Europe authorities have moved to outlaw symbols of support for the Russian military and its invasion of Ukraine. Latvia is the latest country to outlaw displays of the letter V and military and its invasion of Ukraine. Latvia is the latest country to outlaw displays of the letter V and Z. So let's find out more from Matthew in the Cube.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Now, Matthew, what is all the controversy? Well, since the start of the war, the letter Z has appeared on Russian military vehicles as well as on pro-Kremlin social media accounts. It was first shared by Russia's defense ministry alongside the words Zapo-Bedu, literally translating to mean full victory. It was also on display at a recent rally attended by Russian President Vladimir Putin, and gymnast Ivan Kuliak was criticised for brandishing the letter on the podium alongside a Ukrainian athlete at a recent competition. This once ordinary letter, which doesn't actually appear in the Russian Cyrillic alphabet, has become a symbol of propaganda and Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Ukraine's foreign minister, Dmytro Kaleba, has called for a universal ban on the political use of the letter Z, as well as another letter that has appeared on Russian authorities, the letter V.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Well, on Thursday, the Latvian parliament approved an overall ban on the use of this letter at public displays, where people are showing support for, quote, military aggression or war crimes. This brings the letters V and Z in line with other symbols that have been publicly banned in Latvia and other Baltic countries, symbols that show support for Nazi or communist regimes. Lithuanian MPs are debating a similar measure and in Germany, some federal states are now also investigating whether the individual use of the letter Z could constitute a criminal act.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Now this has all generated a response from Moscow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: For example, some state media have been suggesting that this is the beginning of the letter being wiped from existence, suggesting that countries, companies like Zoom or even Ukraine's president, Volodymyr Zelensky, could be changing their name. But this is specifically about the letter being used to show political support for Russia's aggression in Ukraine. The letter Z in Latvia can still be used for educational, scientific or artistic purposes. Helena, this isn't just about the letters being used, as some people are suggesting, but it's more about what these letters represent in the context of the ongoing war in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Fascinating insights. Thank you so much.
